Indoor Positioning–Driven Smart Classroom Lighting with Occupancy Counting

March 5, 2024

This provincial-level startup project addresses inefficient “all-on” teaching-room lighting when occupancy is low or absent. Because PIR sensors only detect significant thermal changes and miss low-amplitude movement, we developed two solutions:

1. RSSI-Based Indoor Positioning

  • Use WiFi Received Signal Strength Indication (RSSI) variations and a BP neural network to model signal fluctuation patterns when people enter the room, inferring their presence and location;
  • Once occupants are located, send wireless control commands via the WiFi module to a microcontroller, which drives the lighting fixtures for targeted, energy-saving illumination.

2. Hardware-Only Infrared + Light Sensing

  • Deploy two spaced infrared transmitter–receiver pairs to count entrants and exits, and use a photoresistor to measure ambient light;
  • Combine headcount and light-level data to decide which lights to switch on, and use a real-time clock chip to enforce lighting schedules without manual checks;
  • Include classroom temperature monitoring and upload occupancy and temperature data to the cloud for students to find available, comfortable study spaces and for teachers to track attendance.
